name: Cobalt(II) nitrate
desc: Cobalt Nitrate is the inorganic cobalt(II) salt of nitric acid, often with various amounts of water. It is more commonly found as a hexahydrate, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, which is a red-brown deliquescent salt that is soluble in water and other polar solvents.
Other names:
Cobaltous nitrate
Nitric acid, cobalt(2+) salt
Boiling point:
100 to 105 °C (212 to 221 °F; 373 to 378 K) decomposes (anhydrous)[citation needed]
74 °C, decomposes (hexahydrate)
Solubility in water:
anhydrous:[1] 84.03 g/100 mL (0 °C)
334.9 g/100 mL (90 °C)

soluble (anhydrous)
Solubility: soluble in alcohol, acetone, ethanol, ammonia (hexahydrate), methanol 2.1 g/100 mL
EU classification (DSD) (outdated):
Carc. Cat. 2
Muta. Cat. 3
Repr. Cat. 2
Toxic (T)
Dangerous for the environment (N)
LD50 (median dose):
434 mg/kg; rat, oral (anhydrous)
691 mg/kg; rat, oral (hexahydrate)
Other anions:
Cobalt(II) sulfate
Cobalt(II) chloride
Cobalt oxalate
standard state:
Except where otherwise noted, data are given for materials in their standard state (at 25 °C [77 °F], 100 kPa).
